description: From Middle English schit, schyt, from Old English *sċite (“dung”) and sċitte (“diarrhoea”), from Proto-West Germanic *skiti and *skittjā, from Proto-Germanic *skitiz, from Proto-Indo-European *skeyd- (“to split, divide, separate”).

Related to Saterland Frisian Skiete, West Frisian skyte, skyt, Dutch schijt, German Low German Schiet, German Scheiße, Swedish and Norwegian Nynorsk skit, Norwegian Bokmål skitt, Icelandic skítur. Compare shite.

adjectives.description: shit (comparative more shit or shitter, superlative most shit or shittest)

examples: What a shit film that was!
That was a shit thing to do to him.

entries.meaning: (countable, uncountable, colloquial, vulgar) Solid excretory product evacuated from the bowels; feces.
examples: Synonyms: see Thesaurus:feces

entries.meaning: (countable, colloquial, vulgar) The act of shitting.

examples: Throw that shit out!
I want your shit out of my garage by tomorrow.
Fuck it. I don't feel like doing this shit.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, colloquial, vulgar, definite, US) (the shit) The best of its kind.
examples: These grapes are the shit!
Synonyms: see Thesaurus:nonsense
Everything he says is a load of shit.

entries.meaning: (countable, vulgar, colloquial) A nasty, despicable person, used particularly of men.
examples: Her son has been a real shit to her.
I am a shit and a rotter.
Synonyms: see Thesaurus:nothing
We don’t have shit to live on. (We don’t have anything to live on.)
John can't sing for shit. (John can't sing at all.)
You ain't shit. (You're nothing; you aren't worth anything.)

entries.meaning: (countable, vulgar, colloquial) The smallest amount of concern or consideration.
examples: Synonyms: fuck, damn
I don't give a shit.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, vulgar, colloquial) A problem or difficult situation.
examples: I'm in some serious shit.
Some shit went down at the nightclub last night.
I gave him shit for being three hours late twice in one week.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, vulgar, colloquial) Any recreational drug (e.g. cannabis, heroin, etc.).
(uncountable, slang, vulgar) Anything exceptional or remarkable.
examples: I heard Bobby escaped from the police by jumping off a bridge into the river. Ain't that some shit?

description: From Middle English schiten, shiten, from Old English scītan, from Proto-West Germanic *skītan, from Proto-Germanic *skītaną, from Proto-Indo-European *skéydt, from *skeyd-, *skeh₁i-d (“to cut”) (compare *skey-).
Cognate with West Frisian skite, Low German schieten, Dutch schijten, German scheißen, Danish skide. More at shed.

verbs.description: shit (third-person singular simple present shits, present participle shitting, simple past shat or (rare) shitted or (US) shit, past participle shat or (rare) shitted or (US) shit or shitten)

examples: Synonyms: see Thesaurus:defecate

entries.meaning: (transitive, vulgar, colloquial) To excrete (something) through the anus.
(transitive, vulgar, colloquial) To fool or try to fool someone; to be deceitful.
examples: Synonyms: shit with; see also Thesaurus:deceive
Twelve hundred dollars!? Are you shitting me!?

entries.meaning: (transitive, vulgar, colloquial, Australia) To annoy. [from 20th c.]
examples: I saw red and smashed a plate and a bowl.  […]  I swept up the mess. I bawled a lot as I swept  […]  I also thought, I am about to get my period. It absolutely shits me that this should explain anything.
